Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about Shakespeare and a medium amount about drama/theater, which I was not quite expecting from this class.

An intensive study of Shakespeare's high tragedies and some of his romances, centered on his powers of characterization. A unique exposure to some of the fundamental problems and questions in each of these plays.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was great, no one will ever beat Professor Bloom
This course doesn't need to be changed in any way, except to change the Skype format back to a proper seminar.

Professor Bloom was always phenomenal. It was a true honor to be his student. As for weakness, I wish we could do the class in-person, i.e. without video chat. Even though the technological set-up often worked flawlessly, it hardly substituted for the original experience in his living room.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Medium class. Bloom now teaches via Skype, which is not an ideal classroom setting. Relatively low-key just one paper, and most focus is on class discussion.
It's Shakespeare, with Bloom. If you get the chance to, take it.

Take this class if you want to go through the main tragedies and romances in Shakespeare's corpus with Harold Bloom. Bloom has some pretty specific readings and opinions of Shakespeare's plays; this will be the only interpretive framework for the course. If that is off-putting to you, you may not learn much. If it is not, this is a great opportunity to learn from probably the greatest literary critic of their generation in a relatively chill, low-stakes seminar environment.
Definitely yes, if you get in. A once-in-a-lifetime experience.
